description.text:
This is a brace that clips on to a soprano recorder. It acts as a third arm coming out of the player's chest. As such, it allows the player to use less effort to hold the recorder. This adaptation was designed for musicians with limb differences to increase accessibility to the recorder.

Users may want to consider covering the recorder clip with felt if using a wooden instrument. In addition, users may want to cover the other end with foam or something else comfortable.

The rod is 100 mm long (4 inches). It was designed for an elementary student to use.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/f8XsMV4tTJ3
Adaptive Music Education This adaptation helps to make the soprano recorder more accessible to students with physical disabilities.

Recorder Adaptation Many music teachers introduce the soprano recorder in upper elementary school. For students with limb differences, the recorder can be challenging, if not impossible. This adaptation can help students with limb differences play more notes on the recorder.

My wife likes to kiss me, but she doesn't like to be prickled by my unshaven maw. Hence she commissioned this tool, which she specified as "a flat thing with a hole in it and a stick". She also named it.

description.text:
I liked the concept by beer92266 because it didn't require supports and would result in strong parts with little load going across layer bonds. But I wanted to make one that would fit snugger to my 13mm diameter posts. I also thought I might as well make a slightly different shape for the other hook as well.

No need to print very solid unless you want to hang bags of rocks from it or something. For the heck of it, I made a single hook set printed a crazy 7 walls thick with petg and was able to hang a 40# bag off it without any sign of stress. With that, I would be more worried about the damage to the upholstery than the hook.

I made some different sizes of each of the hooks, so hopefully you can find one that fits for you. The headrest hook comes in 14 and 18mm diameter hook sizes with 54 and 80mm length options. (measure from front of post to rear of seat)

I made the 14mm dia x 54mm headrest hook and the larger seatback hook part.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

For most applications I'd suggest just printing 2 to 3 layers thick with low infill unless you are going to put a lot of weight them.

A brim is a good idea for these, especially the longer parts.

title: Raspberry Pi Case with OLED SSD1306
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my second Pi Zero Case designed mainly to hold my Pi Zero W , but also works with the normal Pi Zero as well if you are using wifi dongles.

Its designed to allow the Pi to just slide in and the power cord keeps it in place. As it uses a sleeve to hold the Pi it also means it is quite robust and doesnt break mounting lugs and also does not neeed screws or bolts to hold it in.

In addition, the top can take a LED ring for added bling and I run it as a status light off a GPIO pin with a resistor. There is also a hole for a small push button and I monitor this with a script to shutdown the Pi if necessary.

The latest mod was inspired by someone who installed a larger OLED, but I tried here to keep it within the case. As it is rotated 90 degress, I use the luma.oled library and rotate the output and use I2C to communicate with the Pi.
It now runs an instance of PiHole to block adverts from my laptops and mobile devices at home and have added a clock for functionality.

The base now has a title space where i applied some Tip-ex and write the IP address of the box as I have too many now and dont like using hostnames and prefer fixed IP

It all prints easily and the only trick is that i have printed the LED diffuser in PETG with 0% infill.

If you just want it as a case, then you can omit the light ring or print it as a solid.

Hope you like it and it makes a change from the standard flat rectangles.

I'm honestly not sure how good the Kaiburr crystal section will turn out. If you have an SLA printer you could give it a shot, otherwise I wouldn't mess with that version personally! I'll eventually make a version of this when I have time to edit it, and make the crystal section printable separate from the hilt, and then possibly be insert-able in the bottom.

description.text:
Another beer related item just for fun.

I thought it would be fun to have a way to display the beer varieties we've had on tap. I already use the plastic keg caps as labels on my beer tap handles, so why not display them when I'm done? So I made a plastic disk that the caps will snap onto and it has a magnet in it to stick to the side of the refrigerator/kegerator.

You need to order some 18mm round magnets. I ordered some off of amazon https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XGB5D45/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 that have the tape already attached. This plastic disk has an indentation in it that fits these particular magnets perfectly.

Hollow version is just my attempt at cutting down on print time and filament used. I haven't printed one yet, but should work fine.

Printer:

CR-10

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

Not much

Notes:

It's not holding much, so no need to make it strong.

This is a an idler for the Z axis belt of your Prism Reprap (design by by Buback) Its two primary purposes are : to be able to use a longer closed belt, like found for instance in original Mendel belts set, and to dampen the wobbling given by printed Z pulleys (sometimes a little oval). The side effect bonuses are : better belt path with more teeth engaged on the driving and driven pulleys, easy belt tension adjustment.

Usage :
1) You may want to modify the size in openscad depending on your belt length,
the stl file is for a 100 to 110 cm belt.
2) Print.
3) Assemble a 4mm Internal diameter bearing (I used a 624) onto the part with
appropriate washers - I think a 20 mm M4 bolt is fit.
4) Mount your Z motor support on the other side of its extrusion (out of the frame).
5) Mount this idler on the internal side of the extrusion next to the Z pulley.
6) Adjust the tension by sliding it sideways (and possibly the motor mount too).
7) Tighten everything. The downside view picture here on thingiverse could be helpful if you do not get how it goes together. You might have to experiment a bit to find the wall thickness/infill parameter which will give you enough springiness in the horizontal direction but not too much flexing in the vertical. The close-up view of the mounted idler here shows my first attempt, which was flexing too much :)

description.text:

title: Back brace Reinforcement for Taz 1-6 Printers and other 20mm extrusion frames

description.text:
This project is a low cost option for adding significant upper gantry and Z axis stiffness to the Taz frame for all model Taz printers. it uses 3 20mm surplus Taz extrusion (3x 500mm or 1x 510mm and 2x500mm for a Taz 6 specifically) some 55mm long M5 cap head bolts and m5 flange nuts, some 10mm long M5 Cap head bolts and M5 t-nuts and M5 washers (possibly shorter than 10mm i was just grabbing them from the container, will measure when i get a chance), 2 stick on furniture feet (taz 6 flexifeet edition coming soon) and about 1lb of plastic. Any type of plastic should be fine for this application, including PLA. I used Push plastics Black ABS.

Do you need this backbrace project? Prior to printing it, I would have said no. I print at very high speeds generally (120mm/sec on average with higher moves, slower first layer is my general "medium" speed) , so I was looking for a way to reinforce the frame against even higher forces. After bolting this on though, my prints have absolutely no layer offset at all. I was already pretty well dialed in with the openbulilds mods, but this pushes it to the next level.

You can source used 20mm taz extrusions here: https://itworks3d.com/product/aluminum-extrusion-20mm/

Development thread here:
https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=6854

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle ABS

Infill:

85% or better

Notes:

The alternative mount for use with the cable chain mods does require support, all else can be printed without it. And you only need that one if you are running cable chain.

Instructions

There are a couple pieces to this project. First, source your 3 500mm long rods (or 1 510mm long center rod for a 6)

  1. Using the center rod as a base, attach one Taz_Backbrace_back_Crossmember_Mount_left_2_1_a.stl and Taz_Backbrace_back_Crossmember_Mount_right_2_1_a.stl to the top of each end of the center rod using T-nuts and bolts. Attach 2 furnature sticky feet to the surface now designated "the bottom"
  2. Attach the two long Taz_Backbrace_Lower_Short_Crossmember_Mount_Left_1_0_a.stl and Taz_Backbrace_Lower_Short_Crossmember_Mount_right_1_0_a.stl pieces to the "front" surface of that extrusion, perpendicular to the pieces you added to the top.
  3. Attach two more Taz_Backbrace_back_Crossmember_Mount_left_2_1_a.stl and Taz_Backbrace_back_Crossmember_Mount_right_2_1_a.stl to the lower rear corners of your Taz main frame.
  4. Attach the two Taz_Backbrace_Upper_Left_Frame-Mount_1_0_a.stl and Taz_Backbrace_Upper_right_Frame-Mount_1_0_a.stl pieces to the upper rear taz main frame. if you are running the openbuilds setup and have a Z cable chain that needs to go in the area the left one would run, attach the alternate Taz_Backbrace_Upper_Left_frame-mount_Alt_1_0_a.stl instead
  5. Remove the built in support, then attach Taz_Backbrace_Upper_Crossmember_end_left_2_1_a.stl to the top and Taz_Backbrace_Lower_Crossmember_Mount_left_2_1_a.stl to the bottom of one of the side 500mm extrusion crossbars. leave the lower mount bolts loose (10mm m5 bolts and T-nuts with washers I think) Repeat with the right hand side pieces and other crossbar. Use the alternate upper end for the left side if you are running cable chain.
  6. Now bolt the arms to the upper mounts using the 55mm long M5 bolts and M5 nuts. Then bolt them to the rear mount ends.
  7. bolt an Taz_Backbrace_LR_1_0_a.stl to each side of the frame to complete the triangle.
  8. Now attach the two Taz-Backbrace_Standard_Lower-Rail_Mount.stl to the back of the Y frame to the back crossmember. If you have the openbuilds Y components installed, use Taz-Backbrace_openbuilds_Y_Specific_Lower-Rail_Mount.stl .

Thats it. if you have a square frame, everythign bolted up and you are done. Print something and be amazed!

There will be a few additional parts for this in the next few days, an extended openbuilds z rail support, and a rear diagonal crossmember spool arm to take advantage of that new space for dual extruders.

Enjoy!

title: Panzer III L - With Snap Turret - 1-200

description.text:
This Panzer III Ausf. L model does not include Schürzen . I have included a 1:200 model. If you want a 1:100 model just double the size. This model has a snap in turret, i.e. after printing and cleanup just slowly push in the turret into the hull. It will snap in place and won't fall out. The 1:100 scale model looks much better, but 1:200 will kinda fit on a Advanced Squad Leader board and will fit in well on a deluxe ASL map.

It is based on m_bergman's excellent Panzer III Ausf L from Armor pack 3. The snap in joint is derived from the clone trooper model by danzca6 .

Printed on the M3D micro.

11/3/2017 - Beefed up the snap joint. Print the turret as is for a better quality barrel. Print with the barrel pointing to the sky for less clean up.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

150

Notes:

title: JellyFish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The idea of this project was to use 3, 3.5 and 4inch props with 1407-3600kv brushless motors on a frame as short as possible.

We ended up with the "JellyFish", based on an awsome 145mm frame designed by my good friend Brax and a "Jelly" pod modelised by myself.

The pod requires to be printed in flex material so the camera and Vtx can fit in without any problem, this provides also a good protection against crashes.

description.text: Conical lid for wine decanter.

Print with a quite high density and not too small : it must not be too light to stick to the carafe. And please, please, do not print it with the any plastic you get your hands on. You will first kill your wine and second kill yourself.
I use Taulman 3D PETT (FDA approved). If you insist on using PLA, at least use "natural" PLA, and avoid touching the wine with it : PLA itself is quite safe, but it is also a good nest for very unsafe dirt and bacteria.

remixed_from.title: Evolve skateboard belt cover stand GT 97mm

title: Evolve skateboard belt cover stand GTX 97mm

description.text:
This is a replacement belt cover for the Evolve GTX skateboards which also provides a flat surface so you can stand the skateboard on it's end.

This is V3 which has some cosmetic changes and the angle is tweaked very slightly.
This has only been tested with my Bamboo GTX with Evolve's 97mm wheels. Which means if you have different wheels or different weight distribution it may not be balanced.
There are other versions on thingiverse for different wheel sizes.

I also recommend getting some new screws (M4 x 10 screws work well)

USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!

You can see some obvious flaws in it. This is not meant to be a perfectly stable storage solution. It will however allow you to put the board on the ground quickly when at the store or for moments you're carrying your board and need two hands.

It has only been tested on my own skateboard so it may need some tweaking for other setups where the weight isn't distributed as evenly. I'll probably update this as I tweak the appearance of it.

title: Replicator 2 Makerbot Extruder Upgrade Spring Tensioner

description.text: Recently I noticed my Replicator 2 was not feeding the filament properly even with the "free" Makerbot extruder upgrade. I performed the pinch test as the filament was feeding through and noticed that I was able to stop the filament from feeding. After many different modifications I came to realize that the spring that kept the whole thing under tension was just not providing enough tension. So I made this little thing to add some tension. Place it in the bottom notch of the extruder upgrade where the spring normally goes, then attach the spring between the top notch and the new tensioner notch. Print at 0.100 mm if possible. I hope this helps someone with extrusion problems.

title: Kossel Roller Carriage Mount for Magnetic Joint Upgrade

description.text:
First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

This is the part that you will need three of to utilise this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2343169 magnetic joint upgrade when converting a printer with roller-carriage style linear guides, as opposed to HIWIN style linear rails.

The magnetic joint holders that bolt to the linear rails in the prior link bolt directly to these pieces using three M3 bolts. They have been designed so they have the same bolt hole spacing as the HIWIN style linear rails. Then you just need to bolt your wheels on as per usual and mount to your printer.

I tried to keep these as simple as possible and as close to the original 3D model of the part it is replacing so those interested in making the conversion have no troubles understanding what is necessary to complete to make the upgrade.

This is a mount for a Wansview IP Camera onto the front of the FlashForge Creator Pro 3D Printer. It is hinged to move out of the way to open the front door. It has a ratchet mount to adjust the angle, so as t reduce glare and give you a better view of the build plate. The Front Bracket It is designed for the best print orientation. The CP_Camera_Holder need to be oriented as shown in the photos of my slicer screen. Printed at .1mm, it is a very long print, but comes out very nice. When Drilling the printer, be mindful of what is on the other side of the holes. Mine was clear, yours may not be.
Extras you need to finish this are:
1- M6 x 25 Hex Bolt
1 - M6 Wing Nut
5 - M4x 15 Hex Bolts
10 - M4 Washers
5 - M4 nuts

I can print this for you. Just use the Treatstock app and select PSD Printing Service. or you can go to my website and use the Treatstock widget. http://www.psdcomputing.com/3d-printing-services

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This is best printed in ABS for strength.

Filing

Use a small file to file between the hinges. It is supposed to be a tight fit, so the camera will stay in the up position while opening the door

author: grantpsd

description.text:

It was printed at the best definition my printer will produce (0.1) as the thread is tricky to print.
this die fits into my press without any fettling and the standard lee nut screws on without a problem

author: JayNC

description.text:
I had trouble with warping printing parts 2 and 10. This is mainly caused by the on-end-open shape and cannot be fought with bed adhesion.

So I splitted those parts into 3 smaller ones. Now it is easy printable completely warp-free.
Extreme warping caused a complete deformation of the visor edge geometry. Printing in 3 parts will solve the warping issue.

print_settings.Notes:: The cams have large chamfers top and bottom to beef up the pivot. They can take a fair bit of force.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Router circle jig (print in place, 30mm -> unlimited radius)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a circle jig for routers. It has several features not commonly found in other circle jigs.

• It has very minimal hardware requirements, and requires just an m6 threaded rod (cut in two parts of equal length). The rods just screw into the router baseplate.

• You can pin the centre pivot with either a screw through the middle (~4mm Ø), or with small nails (4x holes @ 2mmØ)

• It uses print in place cam locks that lock the cutting radius without changing t he radius (the cams don't contact the threaded rod, instead pressing on a flat plate, so that there is no back or forth movement when tightening them.

• It is able to slide under the router to enable cutting circles with a radius as small as 30mm (centre to centre). With a narrow bit, this could mean holes as small as 63mm across. In addition, it can be extended as far as you're happy to go with m6 rods. I've been using it to cut holes with a radius of 30cm. The wide separation between the rods means it's stable and accurate even with larger radii. Depending on your router you may need to use a countersunk screw for the pivot, to prevent it hitting the router guide.

• The hole layout is designed to match Makita base plates - specifically their XTR01Z 18V router.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

lots

Notes:

This is a print in place. Tolerances are fairly large (0.3-0.4mm), but because it's also printing large pivots it may still require some tweaking to get it to separate. The m6 clamps should free up really easily, but the cams may need a bit of shuffling. I used a scraper to get in between them and the outer plates to free them up.

The cams have large chamfers top and bottom to beef up the pivot. They can take a fair bit of force.

description.text:
This is an easy to make, quick and dirty digitizing probe for a cnc machine. You can use it to generate point clouds and for auto-levelling. Take a look at Mach3's digitizing wizards...

You will need a length of 1/8th" brass tube, 3/32" stainless rod, a tactile switch (6x6x4.5mm), and a 1/8th" tool shank - I used a broken pcb drill bit.

The tactile switch can be bought here: https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/322792083221 - although might be a while before you find uses for the other 99 lol!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Use a brim when printing the body part.

Assembly Instructions

Print the two plastic pieces as they are, with the body standing up on it's pointy end. A brim is probably a good idea.

The length of brass tube is not critical, needs to be long enough to ensure the rod can only move vertically, and short enough to fit between the collet and the work to be digitized.

Cut the rod so it's slightly longer than the brass tube and pein one end over so it can't fall out of the tube. I rounded the other end off with a bench grinder.

Insert the tube into the body part and the shank into the top part as shown in the images. With the rod inserted in the tube, it should just touch the switch button. Adjust the length of shank protruding into the body so it just touches the back of the switch when the two pieces are assembled.

Break off the pins on one side of the switch, and solder wires onto the other two pins, (I used a couple of header pins with some heat shrink) then push the switch into the body. It should be snug fit.Check that the rod will actuate the switch when pushed, you should hear a click from the switch.

Now you can assemble the probe. Screw the two pieces together, if you are happy with the way it works then a drop of superglue will stop it coming apart when in use.

That's it, happy digitizing!

comments.text:
Very cool!
Maybe in a future version you could add a large PCB Pogo Pin (Spring type) to the touch? Many years ago I used the Bob Campbell controller and Gecko drives and no matter what I did in Mach3 when the probe would touch my Z would drop .0250. Maybe a Pogo pin might help with over step if anyone has that issue? Then of course, we used a 1 wire solution and used the machines bed and part as the ground to close the circuit on touch. Anyhoo, awesome stuff and thank you sir for posting it!
comments.author: chewonthis

comments.text: I'm trying to find a way to use a small microswitch in place of the tactile switch so the pressure needed to operate is less The pogo pins are a good idea, if I can find a way to incorporate them I will. Thanks for the suggestion, and thanks for your kind words. :)

title: Double filament sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Filament Sensor based on things Craftbot filament sensor and Filament sensor. Thanks to them !

First of all, I didn't have any tangle problem yet with good filament spool. I just keep an eye on the ending spool... So boring, and we are always distracted at this critical moment.

Last week, an unexpected issue appeared... Filament wasn't perfectly round somewhere in the spool, I noticed oval 1,75 x 2.02mm width... This resulted with an half "air print" and filament stuck on the PTFE tube (PTFE tube from spool to direct extrudeur).

Craftbot filament sensor show me the road but I had different end stop sensor in stock : Example.
Filament sensor gave me the first part.

I designed the second part to fit on the first part and solder 2 endstops in sequence with the first NormalyClosed and the second NormalyOpen (respectively bottom and top endstop).

Now I have end filament sensor and tangle filament sensor (or stuck filament anywhere ;) )

Just wire to raspberry or other board and configure software to pause the print when issue happen.
I use Octoprint with "Filament sensor reloaded" plugin on GPIO24 and GND.

Printer:

Eclip3d V1.2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Place it on the side and add little support bellow PTFE entry and where the endstop goes. Don't put support where filament is going through.
Print also Filament sensor part to couple them.

title: Synscan holder for SkyWatcher Star Discovery / EQ5 / EQ6 mounts

description.text:
SynScan v4 (and v3) holder for the SkyWatcher Star Discovery (aka Orion Starseeker IV) , EQ5 and EQ6 mounts.

This replaces the original velcro bracket that cannot stay in place and always slides down to the ground.

On sturdier mounts, I find more convenient to use velcro on the mount head, see last picture

StarDiscovery version will fit any tripod with 1"1/4 (32mm) round legs.
EQ5 will fit any 1"3/4 (44mm) legs and EQ6 will fit any 2" (52mm) tripod.
Rectangular clamp will fit the 68x30 legs found on some EQ3 and EQ5.
Also provided a clamp that goes on the tripod spacer, remixed from the original thing by RobertCL https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681425

You will need a pair of M3x10mm / M3x12mm hex screws. -- or just print both pieces as one
Print with supports on the bed, 2 walls, 50% infill.

Time lapse of the v4 holder : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZMdw244MVyc
v3 holder and tripod clamp : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UXmUBrGjEm4

comments.text:
Awesome boomerangs. I have made many from .6 to 1.6 scale. The bigger ones need more room to fly. The 'fun' size is somewhere between .8 and 1 scale. It also helped me fine tune my first layer and extrusion settings. I used abs, printed in various layer thicknesses from .1 to .3. Octagram spiral is one of the best fill patterns for strength, especially at the airfoil bends, also so you dont break it when catching and bending it by accident. Its best to bend the airfoil hot off the build plate, that way they dont crack when cold.
You should note in the instructions that the airfoil needs to be bent. I didnt realize it until I watched your video. I was shooting the boomerang into my walls the first time I tried it, lol.
Thank you.

title: RX-2 Chaipattana Low Speed Surface Aerator (Scale Model)

description.text:
Overview

This is a working scale model of the RX-2 Chaipattana Low Speed Surface Aerator.

It was developed in Thailand by King Bhumibol Adulyadej. It has inspired the development and distribution of a wide variety of surface aerator systems now used throughout Thailand to turn otherwise stagnant water into a resource for agriculture, aquaculture, and recreation.

A video demo is available here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7aAWuWEHq0E
A video demo on water is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6kBsjqi_GhY

For more information about the aerator, see here: http://www.progressth.org/2017/10/3d-printed-rx-2-chaipattana-low-speed.html

Details

It uses 12V DC 35byj46 stepper motor and driver board + Arduino Nano.

It requires extensive friction welding to assemble. Use a back light to see where gaps may be to ensure your welds are water-tight. Using aquarium silicon sealer along the welds may also be a good idea. A hole drilled in the top of the pontoons fitted with a stopper could be used to drain the pontoons if they take on water.

The motor housing should be either tack welded (using 4-6 spots of welding instead of a single continuous bead along the seams) or hot glued in place. This allows you to remove the housing to work on or replace the motor in the future. Also at spots of hot glue onto the nuts securing the bolt because they come loose during the aerator's operation.

Info on the welding process including a link with a video can be found here: http://www.progressth.org/2017/07/diy-friction-welding-warped-3d-prints.html

The SketchUp file is include and is also available in SketchUp's 3D Warehouse here: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/0e1db761-46ee-4a45-993e-233a70991783/RX-2-Chaipattana-Low-Speed-Surface-Aerator

The system does float and works on water. If you decide to do this, please exercise EXTREME CAUTION and do so at your own risk.

Printer:

ExtraBot 3020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

20-40%

Notes:

Requires extensive friction welding after printing.

The pontoons warped while printing and required spanning gaps while welding: http://www.progressth.org/2017/07/diy-friction-welding-warped-3d-prints.html

The motor housing should be either tack welded (using 4-6 spots of welding instead of a single continuous bead along the seams) or hot glued in place. This allows you to remove the housing to work on or replace the motor in the future. Also at spots of hot glue onto the nuts securing the bolt because they come loose during the aerator's operation.

title: Bouchon Réservoir Liquide de Frein VW

description.text:
Les deux modèles sont des bouchons pour réservoir de liquide de frein VW après 61.

Vent.stl pour le bouchon ventillé.

Cap1302_Purge.stl permet de relier un tuyau à une pompe pour effectuer une purge des freins. Le diamétre du tube est de 8mm.

Si vous imprimez en dessous de 100 micron et que votre supporte bien les bridges, il ne devrais pas y avoir besoin de support.

Pour éviter les supports le bouchon Cap1302_Purge a un bridge sacrificiel très mince en bas du tube. Il suffit de le perçer avec un tourne vis, foret, etc.

Il faut peintre le bouchon, ou le recouvrir d'epoxi, etc pour le rendre totalement étanche.

comments.text:
Info: Le bouchon de réservoir de liquide de frein est le même sur tous les modèles de cox (à l'exception peut-être des plus anciennes).
Ca fait partis des pièces que VW n'a pas modifié tout au long de la vie de la coccinelle :)

author: Zpsmi

description.text: Lego scythe designed with FreeCad

Check out the whole "T" copter family:
  • TX8 Octocopter
  • T6 Hexacopter
  • T4 Quadcopter (10" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 (7-8" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 (5" props)
  • Tubular Crossfire 2 quadcopter
    I've added a post on the forums over at DIY Drones for discussing and improving these designs.
    Also, check out the T4 build overview video.

• completely 3D printable (without support)
  • simple assembly
  • includes a single motor arm or optionally use the coaxial arms from the T6 and create an X8!!
  • strong braced tube section arms with plenty of room to conceal motor wiring
  • designed for a single 3S or 4S battery located right in the center of rotation/thrust with room for up to a 6000mah 3S or 4200mah 4S battery (155 x 50 x 30mm capacity).
  • easy cable routing with beveled cable "tunnels" (and even a few cable tie mounts)
  • plenty of space to mount ESCs - concealed but still well ventilated for cooling - perfect for a 4-in-1 ESC too.
  • top plate is designed for the new Pixhawk flight controller from 3D Robotics - but is also fine with APM, KK2 and others
  • mounting holes available on the "nose" that can be used to attach things like the included Go Pro vibration mount.
  • RF "invisible" frame - as opposed to carbon fiber or aluminium
  • All-up-weight 1,011 grams (excluding battery of your choice - including 3DR 880KV motors, 4-in-1 ESC, Pixhawk with GPS and telemetry). Still flies great when loaded with another 1kg of batteries and camera gear (see video).
  • Sketchup file included so you can make changes to suit yourself

I've been experimenting to find a strong "tubular" profile that could be printed reliably. The angled sections in these designs are 35 degrees to vertical - so well within the typical 45 degree capability of most printers. They arms only present about 11mm of flat surface to minimize obstruction to airflow.
The rest of the design are a collection of ideas that have accumulated over the past year building various quadcopters and Y6 configurations (3D printed, aluminium and bought frames).

• Flight video with Tarot Gimbal and Go Pro attached
  • Flight video with GoPro mounted on top - no gimbal
  • Tubular arm versus "conventional" arm design

3 August 2014
Version 1.05
Just a small change to add slots to the arm motor mount holes so that 4 bolts can be used (in a 16-19mm pattern) regardless of which "corner" of the motor the wires exit.
1 April 2014
Added a T4 univeral camera plate accessory as a separate thing. 22 March 2014
Version 1.04.1
  • No changes to any existing parts
  • Added a vibration reducing mount for a GoPro Hero 3 - for folks who don't want to set up a full camera gimbal. I used these dampeners because I had them lying around. They removed all vibration "jello" but may be a bit too soft for aggressive flying. I think these ones would be a better option. Anyway, I've included several STLs with different hole sizes which will hopefully suit most dampeners out there (5mm, 7mm, 8.5mm). Flight video is above.
    15 March 2014
    Version 1.04
  • about 12mm narrower "waist" for a small reduction in plastic/weight
  • additional cable tunnels at the front of the flight controller
  • slots in the side and rear of body.stl provide another option to cable tie accessories (eg transmitters with aerials pointing down)
  • small notches out of the bottom tray provide an outlet for cables to run under each arm (eg for lighting strips)
    The following files have been updated:
  • T4Body.stl
  • T4TopPlate.stl
  • T4BottomTray.stl
    I'm also adding the component weights and print time in the instructions.
    • 8 March 2014
    I flew a few different batteries today to compare. This is with my 880kv 3DR motors which is a bit over-weight as it is version 1.00 and has most of the power components from my T6 inside. I'm guessing a 1.02+ version with something like the 3DR 850kv motors would weigh at least 100 grams less with longer flight time.
    The results:
  • 3S 3500mah = 10 minutes (only used 2472 mah - old battery)
  • 3S 6000mah = 18 minutes (used 5676 mah)
  • 4S 4200mah = 16.5 minutes (used 4027 mah)
    Version 1.03: A small update that adds two more holes to the body and top plate near the front cable tunnel. This provides a triangle of fixing points on the "nose" which could be used for "accessories" such as a simple camera mount.
    • 7 March 2014
    CRASHED HARD!! But this frame handled it well (see photo above). I printed off another arm after work, reassembled and had time for a quick test flight - all back to normal. Replacing the arm was about a 10 minute job.
    5 March 2014
    I just noticed a hole missing at the front of the top plate. It's not required (or any real issue if missing) so I've just updated T4TopPlate.stl and the Sketchup file without changing version numbers.
    4 March 2014
    Version 1.02: I've spent another full day drawing on this thing. The biggest parts are now 199mm long and 140mm wide. Hopefully that will squeeze onto a few more print beds out there. The arm will also fit onto that sized bed if you rotate it a bit.
    I've started to version the Sketchup files and left older ones in the files if anyone prefers an earlier design.
    3 March 2014
    Version 1.01: As requested I've put this thing on a diet. It now only requires a 140mm wide (and 220mm long) build platform so it should fit easily on a Replicator 2.
    Also I've updated T4Arm.stl adding a small hole to allow a cable tie to be used for strain relief where the wires exit the motor.

I printed all parts in PLA, 0.25mm layers with 40% infill, 2 shells and 3 top/bottom layers. Feel free to experiment. I didn't play around too much with the settings as these gave me a good strong result.
Calibration test
TubeSocketArm.stl contains a cut-down socket you can use for testing the fit of your arms before committing to the full Body print. I found a 0.1mm clearance between the arm and socket provides a firm press fit. Some light sanding may help if you find the fit too tight but I recommend keeping the tolerance as small as possible.
A quick word about scaling
According to Wikipedia apparently "there is no scale information [in STL files], and the units are arbitrary". There is often confusion with STL files and metric versus imperial (inches) units. I designed these parts in Sketchup using metric units and they import correctly into my slicer (which is also set to metric). If you have issues, check your application to see if has a way to select metric or alternatively scale down by a factor of 25.4.
Also, the Sketchup file contents are scaled up by 1000 (attempt to solve some Sketchup quirks). I scale each component down by 0.001 before exporting the STL so they are in real millimetre sizes.

• 4 arms (40 grams, 2 hour print each*)
  • 1 body (147 grams, 8.5 hour print*)
  • 1 top plate (35 grams, 1.75 hour print*)
  • 1 bottom tray (52 grams, 2.9 hour print*)
  • 1 battery peg
  • 4 legs (optional - long, short, or none)
  • 1 GPS post and plate (optional)
    *times were recorded on my Makergear M2 printer which has a 0.35mm nozzle and was printing at 4500mm/min.
    ...and "hardware"...
  • 8 M3 x 40mm+ bolts (arms to body)
  • 8 M3 x ~5mm bolts (motors to arms)
  • 8 M3 Nyloc nuts and washers
  • approx 3mm x 10mm self-tapping screws (attach top plate and bottom tray)
  • some Kyosho Zeal Gel or similar anti-vibration gel and rubber bands for mounting the flight controller and camera.
  • some foam for padding the battery compartments. I ended up using self adhesive window draft-stop tape from my local DIY store.
  • double sided adhesive foam tape (for mounting other electronics)
  • some cable ties
  • soldering gear and connectors to suit your electrical bits
    ...and stuff to make it fly...
  • 4 motors** (I had some 880KV ones lying around but something like these 850kv ones would be a match)
  • 2 normal propellers and 2 pusher propellers (10 x 4.7 slowfly)
  • 4 20A+ ESC (speed controllers) or a 4-in-1 ESC
  • 1 power distribution assembly (if not using 4-in-1 ESC). I prefer to make my own compact version (like this or this) but you might be able to squash in something like this or this.
  • 1 3DR power module (or BEC - often built in to your ESCs)
  • 1 3S (up to 6000mah) or 4S (up to 4200mah) battery
  • 1 3DR Pixhawk, APM (or other flight controller)
  • 1 Radio control receiver (and transmitter) (eg a Taranis)
  • 1 3DR GPS/compass (optional)
  • a pair of 3DR telemetry radios (optional)
    ** the arms will suit any motor up to 30mm diameter (typically they're 28mm) and with a pair of 19mm mounting holes. This sized motor typically has a 16x19mm mounting pattern but unfortunately the wires on different models exit the motors from different corners so the only way to work with all motors was to provide a 19x19mm hole pattern and mount the motors using only 2 bolts (with Locktite). Experience has proven this is not a problem and, in fact, seems to be common practice - for example all 3D Robotics off-the-shelf vehicles only use 2 bolts to mount their motors.
    • If your new to RC copters then the ArduCopter wiki is a great place to find out everything you need know.
    The default APM parameters for the 3DR Iris should be very close for this quadcopter.
    Some tips from maverik0106:
  • you may need to look quite a distance from the print bed to find the objects in some of these STLs. (I'll work on improving that).
  • he also suggests that Makerbot/Replicator users "do not resize the objects".

comments.text: Is the bottom tray printable without supports? It looks like where the bolt holes are would need support...
comments.author: Kryckter

comments.text: You shouldn't need support.  The bolt holes use a little 3D printing trick I came up with.  The first 0.25mm layer is solid (ie there the hole doesn't go all the way through) so it prints just like any other small bridge.  The hole only starts from the 2nd layer upwards.  That single first layer is so thin that when you are assembling a bolt will push right through it an you wouldn't even know the hole doesn't go all the way through.
comments.author: Kryckter

My motors overheated today and went through the mounting holes in the arms. I used the 3DR motors from the instructions and the 4-in-1 ESC. I've only done a few flight before, during last weekend, when I didn't notice anything.
Today I first flew with a 3S 6000mAh battery (maybe 15 mins) and then changed over to a 4S 4500mAh one. Both are of very similar size/weight. Could the voltage be related to more heat? I wouldn't really think so and rather attribute it to the heat building up over time.

I just did a 15 minute (full speed forward) flight here and checked the motor bolts immediate after landing - they were not even warm to the touch (if anything cooler that my finger temp).  It is a nice winter day here 18 deg Celsius.  I was using a 5200mah 3S battery.  All up flight weight 1.3kg (no camera). Admittedly I bought my 3DR 850KV motors a couple of years ago now so they may be different.

comments.text: The Pixhawk only has provision for a single cable PPM receiver connection (not an 8 PWM cable connection) so you probably need a PPM encoder as described here: http://learnrobotix.com/uavs/quadcopter-build/pixhawk/connecting-turnigy9x-radio-pixhawk-flight-controller.html

comments.text: Hey Brendan.  I love this design.  My quad is in the air and flying great.  Thanks for all the great tips in your instructions.  I know a quad isn't supposed to spend much time upside-down in the grass, but due to my newb-ness I've already discovered the weakest point.  This being the GPS mast mount on the top plate.  One rough landing with a bit of forward momentum caused mine to flip in the grass and broke the mount rather than breaking the mast.  Oh well.  Lesson learned.  Thank goodness for a 3D printer.  I can print another plate and focus on actually learning how to fly!

comments.text: I started printing this out last year, then got sidetracked. i have all the parts.  I'm having a hard time printing the legs though they always want to curl up off the bed plate and end up bowed.  I modified them with big skirts on the ends but they still pulled up.  I'm using a Replicator 2..although my replicator 2 is modified with bottleworks aluminum arms and heated built plate.  so I have a heated built plate and glass surface.  I have been printing onto blue painters tape with PLA and no bed heat.  Will bed heat help? how much.
comments.author: KTMDirtFace

comments.text: I use budget hairspray on glass heated to ~55 degrees Celsius.  At one point I used one of those cheap Infra-red temperature guns to measure the temperature along the length of the part (after it was about 1/3rd printed) and compare with the temperature of the build plate - my theory being to get them as close to each other as possible.  I suspect the issue with long skinny parts is keeping the temperature as close as possible along the full length of the part so it's good if the headed bed element extends all the way to the edges of the build platform.  In saying all that my arms repeatedly print fine without any "skirts" - in fact I typically have to put the glass into the fridge/freezer to get the parts to release (once they've cooled down).
comments.author: KTMDirtFace

comments.text: Bed heat with PLA worked like a charm thank you.
comments.author: Brendan22

comments.text: Ok I'll try some heat. and probably leave the blue tape on ( it really really sticks to the blue tape ).. I usually ruin the tape removing items. I have a full enclosure kit now too and am printing the lower tray currently with no bed heat.. i think the full enclosure is helping keeping temps consitant.

You'll need some sort of flight controller (KK2, Naze32, APM, Pixhawk, etc), a 6+ channel receiver to suit your transmitter. Battery socket to suit the plug on you battery, bolts, nuts, heatshrink, perhaps wire to extend your motors/ESC connections. There always seems to be something I forget :)

comments.text:
Hi,
I flew this quad for the second time today (the first flight was very short) and I had a very frightening problem. After ~9 minutes of flight, the quad dove hard to the front-left and almost hit a tree. I struggled to bring it back and land it but I got it back in one piece with a pretty hard landing. Inspection revealed that the two front motors had gotten so hot that they had started to melt through the PLA arms and pull the bolts through the arms, making them wobble. I fear that if I had been flying for just a few more minutes I would've ended up with both of my front motors no longer connected to my quad, and I think we can all imagine what happens after that.
I'm using the 850Kv motors and 10x4.7 props linked to in the recommended parts, both directly from 3DR.
Has anyone else had this happen to them? If so, how did you fix it?
I was thinking that I could put a few holes in the arms where the motors are to provide a little more cooling, but I don't know if that would be enough.
Any suggestions/thoughts would be greatly appreciated.
comments.author: jackadanos

comments.text: Have you solved this problem? I had exactly the same happen to me today with the 3DR 850KV motors from the instructions :(
comments.author: jackadanos

comments.text: Nope. My quad ended up going splash into the water while hovering at 10ft. I recovered it and sent the logs to 3DR but they basically said they didn't know what happened and couldn't help me. I did put washers and cut out a big portion of the arms around the motors. Check my other comments for pics

comments.text: Oh, sorry to hear that :(

comments.text: I've built aluminium and 3D printed copters.  They will all vibrate unless the props are balanced.  As you can see from one of the screen shots above, the vibration on my T4 are minimal (and less that some of my aluminium attempts :)).  I have no concerns about the strength of the T4 and at least you can print new parts if you do fly into a tree or something - beats waiting for a courier to arrive!  In saying that there are so many cheap off-the-shelf frames out there that you'd probably only bother 3D printing one if you are a bit of an enthusiast.  Buying a proven RTF machine is probably the best way to get started.

The hairspray I use just a basic budget type (not XXX strong). I run the heated bed at 55C - hotter and it seams to cause curling.
My only other pieces of advice are:
1) get the first layer height right. The first lines should look slightly fatter than a normal bead bead of plastic because they are just a little bit squished onto the bed.
2) print the first layer slowly. I'm printing the first layer at 2,880 mm/min (60% of my normal 4,800 mm/min)

comments.author: ShokWaveRider

comments.text: I'm no expert with Sketchup - in fact these T Copters are my first real play with 3D modelling at all.  Several of the hundreds of hours I put into these designs was trying to work around Sketchup quirks. You may just need to try approaching what you are doing a different way.  Sometimes I'd create a face (or shape) somewhere away from the model, group it, then move it into the correct place in the model so it cuts everything it needs to, explode it, Intersect faces with model on each face, and then delete the surplus bits. I'd still run into problems sometime when cutting though curves and Sketchup sometimes slightly moves/joins lines if they get to close to each other - especially on curves.  "Show Hidden Geometry" seems to be useful to turn on occasionally so you can see the hidden lines that Sketchup uses to make curved faces.  I've only been using the free version of Sketchup - you may have more tools available to you.
comments.author: ShokWaveRider

comments.text: Better learn to work with solidworks. Sketchup build incomplete solids. and you have to repair them before printing.

comments.text: In the STL files there is about 0.3mm clearance between the moving plunger and the leg itself.  Your printer may be pouring too much plastic into the part resulting in that clearance being reduced due to the extra plastic "squidging" across the gap.  You could try reducing your extrusion multiplier (or whatever it is called in your slicing software).

comments.text: Hi Brendan! Did you specified special configuration for the 3DR Pixhawk during your purchase? It has options for PPM encoder, digital airspeed sensor, external led and usb, telemetry radios and so on.. If you don't change the configuration it seems like the prices is ~$280..
comments.author: tunix

comments.text:
• Depending on what radio transmitter and receiver you have/buy you might not need the PPM encoder - see http://copter.ardupilot.com/wiki/common-pixhawk-wiring-and-quick-start/#Connect_RC_inputs
  • I've never used an airspeed sensor - they are more often used with the Pixhawk in planes.
  • External led and usb aren't required for the T4 as you can get to the Pixhawk directly without those "extension" options.
  • I DO use telemetry radios so I can connect my PC or Android tablet to the T4 wirelessly (for setup and while in flight) to monitor everything (including remaining battery): http://copter.ardupilot.com/wiki/common-3dr-radio-version-2/
  • If you have an FRSky transmitter (eg Taranis), an "D" type FRSky receiver and a small adapter board it is also now possible to send some telemetry data back to the transmitter directly without seperate radios: http://copter.ardupilot.com/wiki/common-frsky-telemetry/
  • The QBrain could be used to provide power to the Pixhawk BUT the Pixhawk comes with a power module that also provides battery voltage and current info back to the Pixhawk so it can be sent to you (via telemetry). http://copter.ardupilot.com/wiki/common-measuring-battery-voltage-and-current-consumption-with-apm/
comments.author: tunix

comments.text: Btw do I have to buy Power Module when I buy both QBrain ESC and 3DR Pixhawk? I thought QBrain has the Power Module (BEC?) in it?

comments.text: My printer came with an electric heating element in the bed.  Hairspray on glass is a trick to help the first layers stick well to the glass.  It works really well and is almost impossible to pull the parts of the bed until it has cooled down ..and then they just pop right off.
comments.author: tunix

comments.text: Well I just learned that our plate has been changed for convenience. They stick a slippery paper on the plexiglass surface so that the objects can be removed easily. In my case, however, it caused lifting. I solved it by increasing temperature from 230 to 250 'C and used the plexiglass surface instead of the paper side. The result was perfect! :) I got an arm which has almost a flat bottom. I'm now printing the 4th one!

comments.text: ...the arm sockets have 0.1mm clearance around the arms.  If you draw yourself a 25mm square that would become the outside flats of the arm.  The top/bottom faces are 11mm wide and the side faces are 5mm high.  Based on that cut the corners with diagonals and that would be the outside arm profile done. The "wall thickess" of the arm is 2mm and the vertical beam inside the arm is also 2mm wide.  Extrude that shape for as long as you want the arm and that's the basic "tube" bit done.
comments.author: MartinKa

comments.text: Just for an FYI, I believe I figured out some of my stability issues. I was using a 4s battery with the 850kV 3DR motors and 10x4.7 props. This setup is definitely over working my motors and ESCs. They get quite warm and makes the copter unresponsive and hard to tune. It is recommended to use 8in props with 4s batteries. I switched to a 3s battery and definitely like night and day the autotune went in perfect and now flys like a champ.

comments.text: The thrust available to lift your T4 will depend on the motors, props, and battery voltage you choose.  I have flown my T4 carrying a 6,000mah battery, Tarot gimbal and GoPro camera which adds up to about 500g more than flying with just a 3,000mah battery ...and it flew fine.   Ideally you want it to hover at somewhere between 40 and 60% throttle.  I expect you'll be fine - give it a try :-)

comments.author: Brendan22

comments.text: DJI motors, along with a lot of others, have a different but standard 16/19mm bolt pattern.  Had to rejig the arms with this bolt pattern.  Seems to work well.
comments.author: eriksu

comments.text: Most of my motors here have got a 16/19mm pattern - but they are not consistent with which corner the wires come out.  To enable all of these motors to point their wires directly down the arm I made the arm with a 19/19mm pattern and only use two bolts to secure the motors.  Using 2 bolts to secure the motors seems to be the normal practice (all of my 3DR purchased copters only use 2).  Did the 19/19mm pattern not give you an option for the DJI motors - or did you just rejig the arms to enable 4 bolts?
comments.author: Zebble

comments.text:
Interesting... I've always used 4 bolts, including on DJI frames. Never thought of using 2, but would definitely make things simpler!
The rejigged 16/19mm pattern worked perfectly for the DJI motors, and with some RCTimer HP2212-1000kv's. They both seemed to have the same pattern and wire position.

comments.author: Brendan22

comments.text: Shorter is a problem as it is mostly constrained by the location of the props, the length of the battery compartment and the center of gravity.  The front and rear props are already only about 10mm from touching (similar to the 3DR Iris) and I really want to try and retain the battery capacity. That said, if you removed the rounded front all-together you'd gain about 18mm and then cutting the back off straight across the vertical posts would save about another 4mm so you might just squeeze in.  I'm not in a hurry to do a chopped version just yet though.  You are welcome to have a go at the Sketchup file yourself - but please post your result for others to use too.

title: Flor de Lis (Fleur-de-Lis)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Varias flores de lis

La flor de lis es el principal elemento en el logo de la mayoría de organizaciones scout. Las tres hojas o pétalos representan las tres partes de la promesa scout (deber hacia dios y la patria, hacia uno mismo y hacia los demás). Robert Baden-Powell, fundador del movimiento scout, dijo que escogió la flor de lis porque en las rosas de los vientos apunta siempre hacia adelante (arriba), nunca a derecha o izquierda, caminos que llevan de nuevo hacia atrás. Las dos estrellas de cinco puntas representan la verdad y el conocimiento, sus diez puntas aluden a las diez leyes scout. El nudo de rizo representa la fuerza del movimiento Scout Mundial y la cuerda la unidad y hermandad de los Scout alrededor del mundo, el anillo de los pétalos, la fuerza de esa hermandad.

Post en Facebook. Si haces uno etiquétate en nuestra foto o etiquétanos en las tuyas.

⋆ ✢ ✣ ✤ ✥ ✦ ✧ ✩ ✪ ✫ ✬ ✭ ✮ ✯ ✰ ★

Many fleurs-de-lis

The fleur-de-lis is the main element in the logo of most Scouting organizations. The three petals or leaves represent the threefold Scout Promise (Duty to God and Country, Duty to Self, Duty to Others). Robert Baden-Powell, the founder of the Scouting movement, explained that the Scouts adopted the fleur-de-lis symbol from its use in the compass rose because it "points in the right direction (and upwards) turning neither to the right nor left, since these lead backward again." The two small five-point stars stand for truth and knowledge. Together their ten points represent the ten original Scout laws. The reef knot or square knot represents the strength of World Scouting. The rope is for the unity of Scouts throughout the world. The ring holding the petals together represents the bond of brotherhood.

Post in Facebook. If you make one, tag yourself in our photo or tag us in yours.

title: 5 Gallon Cyclone Dust Collector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Printed parts for a two Bucket/Lid Thien Baffle Dust Collector

Top Lid and Port

I made a 10" diameter 5/8" thick plywood insert with a 2.5" center hole to support the top hole port. The top hole port is screwed to the plywood and the top bucket lid is then screwed to the plywood disk.

Side Port

For the side port I trimmed part of the bucket side rim away to raise the port higher on the bucket. I then attached the side port with screws, held the bucket up to the light, and traced around what needed to be removed to create the side port in the bucket.

Top Bucket Bottom

A 1.5" slot was cut into the bottom of the top bucket about a third of the way around to allow the dust cyclone to drop into the bottom bucket.

Bottom Bucket Lid

The lid on the bottom bucket has most of the inner top removed to allow for a tight fit on the top bucket without is sinking all the way down into the bottom bucket.

Hopefully the included photos can show the assembly and how I used the two buckets and lids.

Once you have everything dry fitted you may want to remove the printed top and side ports to add sealant.

comments.text: How well is yours working?  What keeps the dust from just short-cutting the cyclone and getting sucked directly into the vacuum port at the top of the bucket?  I printed one for myself but only have the one bucket so far and I notice most of the dust is getting through to the vacuum still.

comments.text: Mine is working very well. I think your issue is the lack of a second bucket.

print_settings.Notes:: Turn off infill but make the walls so thick that you get 100% fill.  This avoids the zig-zagging infill does and infill also seems to be slower.

description.text:
Revision: Added OpenSCAD File

This is an improved version of my other tri-mesh design "www.thingiverse.com/thing:1874263". The surfaces are smoother so it behaves more slippery under tension and seems a little stronger. It also scales up better without looking jagged.

The original model was made in OpenSCAD in high resolution but the file is very large. It was then run through the decimation routine in Blender which reduced the size by 16x without losing much resolution. Both versions are included

The 4-ring version can be patterned in x and y to make any size square mesh that will fit on your bed. The x spacing is 31.05mm and the y spacing is 17.93mm. I have used both FreeCAD and TinkerCAD to do the patterning. Your slicer may also be able to do it. The include 5x9 pattern will fit on a 200mmX200mm bed.

I have had good luck using PLA and PETG with a bed covered in blue tape and coated with diluted white glue. Keep an eye on the first few layers to make sure it is OK. The large 5x9 mesh has 540 pads on the first layer and they all have to stick! I have had no luck getting ABS to stick.

There is a way to join these patterns to make even larger sizes. Just snip the edge rings in a non-obvious place and snap them over the mating rings. The "bracelet" was made by joining 2 of the 3x5 patterns together.

Of the many uses, you can put one on your head and it will induce calming and centering as Annie demonstrates in the picture :).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%*

Notes:
  • Turn off infill but make the walls so thick that you get 100% fill. This avoids the zig-zagging infill does and infill also seems to be slower.

author: enjoyyyy

description.text:
Cool your whiskey faster and keep it stronger longer with this whiskey ice ball maker.  Just fill bottom cup to the "fill line" with water and insert the top cup and pop in the freezer.  There is an 0.010" interference over 1/16" to seal between top and bottom...an o-ring or Sugru seal may work better.  Make sure to let me know how it works for you!  
There should be a small overflow out of the top hole.  
Takes about 4 hours to fully solidify.  
Run under warm water to help separate and release.

description.text: So This Has A lot of rules here they are: Big snakes are albino. You cant win with your albino. 2 player game. Each Player Has 1 albino and 3 normals. if your snakes die 30 times they die for good. Wholes in the board allow you to go double the amount you rolled. when you go in the pit you stop moving. if the enemy is on one of the spawns PS the spawns are the row with the 3 only 3 snakes aloud. Use 2 6 sided dice. PS if 2 snakes are on any of the spaces outside of the spawn row you each roll a dies whoever gets more does not leave the space the one who got less dies. one more thing you both each roll a die at the same time but whoever stops faster goes first. one more if you do a move after 3 seconds you cannot change your move. and you snake is coiled. albinos cant die. The objective is to get all the snakes of the board.

title: Footy Class R/C Yacht Green Hornet

description.text:
You can print your own R/C racing yacht and have it on the water in a week.

Green Hornet is a Footy Class sailboat that can be used for fun in your swimming pool or as a highly competitive race boat for international competition. You can find information about the Footy Class at http://footy.rcsailing.net/

Print files are provided for the complete hull, fin, and rudder. You may need to resize the fin and rudder before printing. I recommend that the fin be 45mm wide and 200mm long. The rudder should be 35mm wide and 150mm long.

Complete instructions for assembling your Footy are at https://3dprintedradioyachts.com/ where you will also find much useful information on printing 3D boats from Footy size to IOM.

I design my boats using FreeShip, an open source CAD program developed specifically for boat design. I export a completed boat to a .igs file that my friend Selwyn Holland prepares for printing using Simplify.

comments.text: Hi Bill, just to make sure you don't miss it: I updated my make, finally I was able to maiden the boat! Great fun, and very impressive how well the hull and deck design works under pressure downwind! Great design, thank you!
comments.author: GER776

comments.text: Hey Bill:  The University of Houston Library, where I work, just purchased two 3D printers and they are working on little projects to demonstrate the capabilities.  Makerspace environment being developed.  I have thrown my hat into the ring to produce one of these so fingers crossed.  This is definitely one of the bigger projects that they have been challenged with.    If we are able to do this, I will keep everyone informed on progress and hopefully final build.  Thanks so much for having this available to us to utilize.
comments.author: rcsailor150

comments.text:
Hi Bill, thank you for posting this, the Footy class looks crazy enough to give it a try!
Stupid question, am new to Footys: Your STL comes out at 319 mm length. In the rules, I am reading about max. 305 mm length. Should I scale the hull down to 305 mm? Or is there something off in my software?
Regards from Tokyo, Philipp
comments.author: GER776

comments.text: Phillip, it’s intended to be 319mm.  The Footy rule is a “box rule” which allows the boat to be placed diagonally in the box.  If you assemble it according to the instructions, the boat will fit in the box and be legal for competition.
comments.author: GER776

comments.text:
Here we go, it fits!! (Not that I had the slightest doubt, nooo.. ;) ) just had a hard time wrapping my head around this box idea, and how it influences rig movement etc... I was actually considering to print the box with some leftover filament ;) but this experiment in CAD shows that the Green Hornet is a much easier fit than a Pool Shark...
Hull and appendages have printed nicely, so I quickly designed some printed parts for mast and keel box and rudder tube. Let's see if these are any good...
comments.author: BillHagerup

comments.text: PoolShark is a double-diagonal hull.  Chris designed it to maximize waterline length, so it fits diagonally in the box in both horizontal and vertical planes.  It's a great boat, but I prefer to work with just the horizontal plane which allows me to use a more efficient rig than Chris was able to design to work with the PoolShark.
comments.author: GER776

comments.text:
ah-HA! Thanks for the instant reply! Need to think inside of the box then... this happens when RG65 guys have a look at the Footy class...
starting the printer now :)
Philipp

Hello!   
I've made this pen holder that allows a slight movement in the Z-axis direction with minimal translation in X and Y. It's the same part printed twice and installed on the mounting plate using M5 screws. There is space for a small bolt and nut to be inserted in the front side, to fix the pen. The maximum pen diameter that can be inserted is 12.5 mm.   
It needs to be printed flat so it's stronger in flexion!  
I hope it could be useful.  
Cheers!

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro b X Axis Cable Chain

description.text:
I decided to redesign the two mounts because of probable problems with the display scroll button in the way of the chain.

On the one side the mount is screwed to the extruder stepper motor and on the other side to the x axis stepper motor. You need to replace the original screws of the extruder stepper motor with longer ones.

With the original extruder stepper cable the z-axis is limited to about 170mm.

You will need 16 of the chain pieces.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Duplicator i3 hotend silicone insulation sock

description.text:
Remix of Crazydog's Hotend Mold. - Shout-out to him!

This remix is thinner (3mm vs 4mm silicone) and with bevels so it has better compatibility with Hotend cooling ducts. This one ist completely compatible with Thorped's Fan Duct which im using.

While the Extruder is only slightly modified from Crazydog's version, the Mold is completely new.

Compatible with Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 with the Heaterblock dimensions: 19.5 x 19.5 x 13.5 mm
And probably re-brands of the Duplicator i3 V2.1 as well.

Update!
New bigger version (Name of the new files is "_big"):
Old version had 2.5mm thick silicone walls, the new has 4.5mm on each side. Top and bottom is still 2.5mm to keep clearance.
I uploaded new pictures as well, as you can see it is still kompatible with Thorped's Fan Duct.

With the Hotend to 250°C the surface of the silicone gets 125°C hot with the new one, with the old silicone sock I got >150°C!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.16mm

Infill:

30%

What you need:

  • A file to make the parts fit into each other tightly
  • Heat resistant silicone (I used Trollfactory 2 component silicone for tin casting - resistant up to 450°C)
  • Small scissors for touch ups of the silicone
  1. File of the irregularities of the smaller square hole and the cube on the bottom part so it fits tightly in the case.
  2. File of the outsides of the four beams on the hotend so that if fit in the mold.
  3. Mix you silicone together (you'll need about 14-16 gram) in an plastic cup or similar. (don't use that for food afterwards!!)
  4. Pur in the Silicone to about 2/3 or 3/4 of the Mold.
  5. Put in the Hotend slowly, press it down and align it good. The silicone should be covering it and about exactly as high as the case.
  6. If the friction doesn't hold everything together, use tape.
  7. Wait until silicone is hardened out.
  8. Take of the bottom of the mold, push out the silicone/Hotend from the mold case, get the Extruder out.
  9. Do little touch ups with small scissors, the holes are probably still covered by a thin layer of the Silicone
  10. Mount it on the printers Hotend. (The Hotend must be free of the previous insulation!)

comments.text:
The mold parts need to be resized a tiny bit, maybe just in the slicer, maybe by 1/3 mm or so
If you print them as is once you assemble them they are so tight the base breaks when you try to separate them
comments.author: gbass01

comments.text: I changed the mold parts a bit, the areas to grip with your fingers when separating are now bigger, the bottom part is 1mm thicker to be more durable and the bottom-cube is now 0.2 mm less from each side (so 0.4 x 0.4 mm smaller). Rasping of imperfections with a file is still necessary but its easier to fit now!
comments.author: gbass01

comments.text:
The problem with that is, that depending on you slicer settings (Feedrate etc.) im guessing everyone will get different results, thats why a file (I uses an small nailfile^^) is definitely needed.
Im looking into it to make an version with the cube on the bottom a bit smaller, and the rectangle under it 1mm thicker. But still then the case and the cube on the bottom will probably have imperfections that have to be rasped away.
comments.author: gbass01

comments.text: I filed the bottom just enough to get it in the hole, but PETG is so springy, it'll let you force things together even if they're still too tight

description.text:
I had many lengths of PVC tube at my disposal, but most mounts seemed to be tailored for 32mm PVC tube. I am building a dry box, so designed the mount to fit on the inside of the clear box (see pictures).

The two extended arms provide retention of the PVC tube, giving a satisfying snapping action when inserting the tube. The support can be fastened using M3 bolts and M3 nuts (which should fit snugly in the hex depresions).

I printed using PLA+

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used rectilinear for partial infill and hilbert curve for solid infill.

I would recomend using rectilinear for both as the hilbert curve nudged the circles and the outer perimiter causing a slight burr.

None required - use straight away!
M3x12 and M3 half nuts
Used PTC Creo to model, and pattern the holes for the nut such that the edges of the hex were rotated to maintain perpendicularity with the centre of the mount.

I have one of the common mass-produced Han Solo belts and loved these gadgets, but found that the gas canister was too big, and the power packs were too small. So, I remixed the canister to be 16mm in diameter and did not change the height. It does indeed work well to print it inverted with a brim. I also made a little "cap" for it because I didn't have any silver paint around, but did have some silver filament. I also remixed the power packs to be 16mm x 43mm x 56mm, which is the same size as the "tic-tac" boxes I had used previously. Then I decided to make the "terminals" a separate piece, so I wouldn't have to do a filament change from white to silver. One version I put holes in the top and used the tall terminals and just press fit them in, and the other I used the flat top version with the short terminals glued on. In the pics, the holes version is the one on the right closest to the gas canister. The terminals are tricky to print due to their small size and lack of cooling, so helps to print several at a time. Mine came out kind of gooey, but I was in a hurry leaving for a costume party literally as these came of the printer and maybe they look good like that anyway.

Big thanks to Sean for the original designs. May The Force Be With You!

The tool was made to fit on a drill, but I find that there is no need for that as hand rubbing is more predictable and effective.

author: Nirbhay

print_settings.Resolution:: What ever you like to test

description.text:
In addition to my EasyCalibration part, which I use for all filaments, I was looking for something to simply show the overhangs that really work. As my overhangs are often not just on one side (and influenced by the position of the cooling fan), I opted for an OverhangCalibration like a vase, which gives me a simple clue as what is working and what are the problems.

OverhangCalib3 prints quickly in less than 30 minutes and shows you exactly where problems occur. Thin wall (1mm) with engraved angle of 40° to 60°. Shows you:

  • Angle that works with the desired layer height
  • Differences around the part depend on the cooling position
  • Deformation of the thin walls
  • Stringing and overextrusion
  • Not enough partial cooling -> minimal layer time
  • Slipping filament -> too hot or layer height too big for this overhang

Along with my EasyCalibration thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023717) this is my most used thing to calibrate my filaments. It also suppressed the LayerBondingCalibration thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2182560) something; I use it now only for ABS or very critical materials.

Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: i provided the lid for convenience so you would not have to go get it from the original, but nothing about it has been modified. all credit for this well designed box goes to theronin, all i did was slap a divider onto his design.

description.text:
this is just an extra option i quickly whipped up for this amazingly designed box, There is no single divide option in the origional design so i made one, there is 2 variations, one is centered divide and one is roughly a quarter-3 quarter split.

No supports needed, also this box can be scaled in all sorts of ways (as well as the origional designs). I have printed in ABS and PLA and am currently trying one with woodfill.

I do find that the ABS ones keep up with daily abuse more. I am an electrician and i use these for screws and batteries and spare small parts of all kinds, i toss them into a bag where they are crushed and tossed around and the lids always stay on.

the only time i had an issue with the lids not holding up to being tossed around was one where i scaled it along the y axis at 150% to make a very long rectangular box that would hold drill bits. it still stays on but if i throw it into my bag the lid flys off and out goes my drill bits. I plan to upload a version that is long but not stretched, this way the notched area will remain the proper length.

my favorite scale of this is 130% on x axis and 90% z axis, especially on the 4 and 6 part boxes from the original design. this makes them with super tough lids and a shorter box makes it easier to grab out small parts.

the smallest i've ever made these boxes was scaled 50% even scale and 85% on z axis.
below 50% the lids didnt even print. but again, this is a fixable thing and i may even upload a tiny version of this.
